Cool, looks good!
So as noted in #chat.zulip.org > experiments, this is test-deployed here!

I've already found it to be slightly useful. One observation is that I think I'd prefer a slightly darker font, perhaps the 0.7 opacity that we use for many grey elements, not the 0.5 that it currently has. But otherwise I'm basically happy with the user experience.

The other thought that I have is that after merging this, we'll probably want to open an issue to add the same indicator in "Recent topics", and adjust the design for the "Inbox" view to include it as well, since those have a similar role to the left sidebar.
In theory we could do the same thing with private messages, but I'm not sure I see it as being useful, since mentions don't modify the notifications behavior in private messages.

Tim Abbott said:

In theory we could do the same thing with private messages, but I'm not sure I see it as being useful, since mentions don't modify the notifications behavior in private messages.

I agree, it makes no sense for Private messages to have @ indication.

After this getting merged, what do you guys think about changing the @ to the icon which Vlad Korobov has provided above ?
Also I would like to know your thoughts about if we decide to use this icon then shouldn't we change the it in the complete application to use this new icon and replace the old one which we have beside Mentions in global filters.
Yes, we should change both icons. As Vlad Korobov indicated above, the sizes are different in the two places.
Can we do that now rather than waiting to merge this change? I'm pretty sure we'll move forward with it, and I would certainly prefer to have the icon we intend before this goes out to everyone.

Could we add a bit of space to the left of the @-icon? This feels too tight to me:

Screen-Shot-2022-08-25-at-2.39.01-PM.png
@Jai soni can you take care of adding space to the left to fix that issue? I think a 2px left margin works; am going to test-deploy that.

So we have @ icons appearing in ~4 places in the app:

  • What you type in the compose box, by definition an @ character.
  • Actual mention pills, currently an @ character.
  • /#settings/notifications, currently an @ character.
  • The left sidebar "Mentions" view icon, currently fa-at
  • User popovers "Copy mention syntax" element, currently fa-at

This feature prototype uses an @ character, which I think does look significant better than fa-at in this context.

I propose we not block this feature on aligning those icons with each other, and instead do a follow-up PR that changes all the @s we have in the app to the same thing. Doing so would save me significant integration headaches.

I think the @ character is fairly defensible since it looks decent and will match what you type in the compose box, or we can use the Feather icon; I don't like the Font Awesome one, so would not push for that. But I think it's reasonable to think of the project to create sanity in our @s across the app as its own mini project.

Tim Abbott said:

Jai soni can you take care of adding space to the left to fix that issue? I think a 2px left margin works; am going to test-deploy that.

Cool, I'll test this 2px margin and push it into the PR if looks fine;
Thanks Tim Abbott for pushing it currently in the test-deployed version.

Tim Abbott said:

I think the @ character is fairly defensible since it looks decent and will match what you type in the compose box, or we can use the Feather icon; I don't like the Font Awesome one, so would not push for that. But I think it's reasonable to think of the project to create sanity in our @s across the app as its own mini project.

Yeah I think the @ character too looks fine and is far better than the fa-icon we have currently in The left sidebar "Mentions" view icon so would like to know @Alya Abbott 's thoughts about this whether we want to do some sort of prototyping for it ?
Hm, I'm confused. Why not try the icon that Vlad posted above?

OK, let me try this in another new PR and I've pushed 2px margin-left in #22583 as it looked fine to me on my local too;
image.png

Alya Abbott said:

Hm, I'm confused. Why not try the icon that Vlad posted above?

We absolutely should -- I'm just proposing "trying it" should mean actually changing all 6 places to it rather than only using it in just the one, which I don't want to bundle into this PR because that sort of change can be fiddly in its own way that's independent from the 300+ lines of live update logic that is this feature (it'll probably need some CSS fiddling because of sizing issues and whatnot).
It'll be way easier to review and integrate that way.
I agree.
Ok, sure, sounds like a plan -- I hadn't realized the level of complexity involved.

Merged #21637. I think we need to open two follow-up issues:

  • As discussed, changing the @ symbol used across the app to be consistent as discussed above.
  • Adding the same style of indicator to "Recent topics".
I filed Use the same @ symbol everywhere #22816.

For Recent topics, I wonder if we should remove the "mute topic" button first, which I think we're planning to do as part of the redesign? Otherwise, I'm worried about having the @ and the mute topic button on two sides of the unread marker. It might look odd visually, and it feels awkward from a UI perspective, as the @ is an indicator, while "mute topic" is an action button.
I think the font color will differ significantly between the @ and the "mute topic" icon, so I'm not sure it'd be a problem in practice.
But I guess it'd also be fine to decide we're removing "Mute topic" from that UI (or moving it into a \vdots menu if we think we're going to want a menu) first.

In the discussion above, we decided not to show @-mention indicators for private messages in the left sidebar. Thinking about this more, this feels inconsistent to me, as we do include PM @-mentions in the @-mentions tab.

Do folks think it would be better to add the @-indicator for private messages, both in the left sidebar and in Recent conversations?

I think it's reasonable to plan to do so for consistency. From a usability standpoint, it may be more work than it's worth; I don't remember the details of the plumbing enough to say how much work it'd be to compute/plumb the data in a performant way (the UI part should be easy).
